review_title: Only If You Have No Other Choice
pros: The people you work with really make or break your job. The people here are absolutely amazing, and somehow everyone keeps everyone going even through the worst of times. The teamwork abilities and determination of my teammates is what is keeping me here.
cons: You're "forced" to work over 40 hours a week (it's at 12% overtime right now) with no overtime pay. By forced, I mean you can work less but it will be held against you during mid/end year reviews, when you're trying to get promoted, or move groups. It's seen as a negative aspect if you're not working that ~45 hours or more. Health insurance isn't very good at all, and raises at the end of the year aren't higher than 2-3%, and that's if you're lucky. The moral is very very low because of how the company treats the employees, and that drives a lot of people to other companies and to retire earlier than planned. The process of getting promoted is very difficult as well. You have to wait for your manager (and other higher ups) to open up a job req, you have to apply, fully interview, and be "selected". Promotions don't happen very often so people just leave the company or move groups to move up. People who transfer into the company from other companies also get paid 5-15k more than someone in the same position that's been at the company from the start so there's a large pay gap between people doing the same jobs.

review_title: Out of touch with the needs of today's workforce
pros: The Aerospace product lines are high impact and wide-reaching, so the work can be rewarding. Benefits are decent for vested employees, but not great. My advice: get your start here to gain experience in the field, but don't stay longer than 5 years.
cons: While the stock prices rise, and the CEO rakes in over $20M, Honeywell Aerospace employees did not receive raises in 2016. Further, nearly all non-manufacturing employees had to take 2 weeks of unpaid furlough so far this year (we expect to be asked to take another by the end of the year). There have also been 2 rounds of layoffs this year with another round coming in November. The icing on the cake is the new Aerospace Remote Working policy that basically eliminates that option for nearly all Aerospace employees. The ability to work remote at least part of the week in an area that suffers from extreme traffic congestion was a huge perk that is now being revoked. It is the last straw for many of my colleagues. While many other companies are ditching the traditional 40 hour work week at the office in favor of more flexible schedules and telecommuting options, Honeywell once again proves just how out of touch it is with technology and today’s workforce. How does the company expect to attract and retain top talent with such outdated, old school thinking?  It’s a shame because the products people work on in Aerospace are pretty cool, but that cool factor only goes so far.

pros: Honeywell gives employees great opportunity to travel around the world when necessary to visit co-sources in other countries or team members that you have worked with virtually. There is so much work on conference calls that you lose the people connection so traveling is a key component. I like the way Honeywell enables managers to direct their own resources. I feel that I have a direct responsiblity to make my team successful with the clear goals that my manager provides. I feel challenged in the work that I do because of the aggressive goals that I am asked to meet. It makes the reward (often small monetary "bravo" bonuses) feel earned.
cons: Many people are often expected to know more than your job description initially entailed. People work beyond their strong knowledge areas and often is harder on them and not as rewarding as it may not be where their interests lie. I believe that this eats away at morale due to the time it takes people away from their friends and family outside of work. Because we are global there is a lot of time spent doing these heavy workloads outside of normal office hours. As these resources hit burnout and leave, we are unable to hire externally in many cases which only increases the burden on current employees or forces us to hire internally from a pool of resources that might not be the most qualified for that position. I know this isn't the case in all of the Honeywell groups, so take this with a grain of salt.

review_title: Sr Technician Lead at Honeywell International in Clearwater, FL
job_title: Senior Technician Lead in Clearwater, FL
pros: Engineering has the best teams to work with regardless of space or defense.  Growth is quick if you're in engineering or in general Engineering Test Services groups as a Technician. Highly recommended getting hired under the ETS Group or any Engineering group regardless if you're looking for a technical, engineering, or management role.
cons: Most management is numbers driven regardless of how much quality is affected. Design engineering is quality driven however. In general for production they don't get employees involved before making changes to the processes or procedures. If you're in a position that you're over qualified for or any other reason you may want to leave. The hiring manager has the right to keep you in that position until 18 months to avoid the hassle of finding someone else internally regardless of how unhappy you're in your current role.  HR can't assist no matter how unhappy you're. If going for a technical or engineering role, avoid Production and Customer Repair Center if possible.  This has the least amount of experienced managers, unprofessional environments (in a bad way), and is overall the most avoided areas when you ask around the company. Go with recommendation from the Pro section. Also, Health Insurance... you're better off going privately.  This company doesn't like to invest money into it's employees, future, or maintaining current environments until a failure or major situation occurs.

pros:
Still have some of the best benefits in the industry (although they are steadily eroding). Full pension (although the medical supplement for retirees was recently dropped), 100% 401K match up to 4% of salary (just reduced from 8%...hopefully temporary but they're not saying, decent vacation accrual  and good medical/dental/vision. It is very easy to cross divisions and product lines if you want to expand your career choices.

The new Honeywell has brought some much needed discipline to some of the practices of the old Honeywell, but at a price far in excess of the benefit.
cons:
That family feel is gone..., what was once a large company with a small company feel is now a bloated bureaucracy mired in "process" and unable to react nimbly and effectively to changing conditions..., with the exception of reducing budget.

The next quarter bottom line is obviously King here now, at the expense of customer satisfacion, general business ethics and certainly the emplyee. We've pretty much alienated every major customer we have through late deliveries, poor quality product releases and refusal to fix product and promised functionality to meet original commitments. Engineering has lost most if not all of their momentum budgets so funding to address issues or opportunities  that crop up unexpectedly is doled out scrouge-like if at all. Hiring to meet only committed projects makes accomplishing off plan efforts that ARE funded dicey at best.

Loss of production resources, software engineering and increasingly systems engineering is pointing to a company goal focused on managing products rather than engineering products.

Very little new development engineering on the horizon.

review_title: It sounds bad but it really was not that bad!
pros:
Benefits are excellent (vacation, holidays, personal days, 401k, medical, dental and eye, long and short  term disability, life insurance, etc.). They also pay for your education.  I got two degrees while working for Honeywell.  Honeywell Aerospace is one of the last to have layoffs when the economy is not doing very well. The company is financially strong. They have never been underfunded in their retirement fund.
Management is very good at telling everyone what is going on with the company, where they stand and where they are heading in the future. There is a cafeteria open all day as well as a company store.
cons: I do not care who gets hired for a job just as long as they are better qualified than others applying for the same position. To meet their "quota" they tend to favor minorities when hiring even when they are not fully qualified or as qualified as many applying. I have witness this several times. I have also seen Honeywell make a special job position and title for one employee just because they had no where to advance but then refuse to do it for other individuals. You are required to go to company meetings (on their time!) and also to take certain self improvement and training courses. Honeywell is a very buracratic company that does things just because that is the way it has always been done. The culture is, right or wrong, do as you are told and do not say anything otherwise you will labeled as a "trouble maker".

review_title: Global company with terrible office politics
pros:
1. Global company that is working on some cutting edge technologies
2. If you are looking for new exposure, Honeywell's various business lines can offer that. The company is open to moving employees around
cons:
1. You wouldn't believe the India back-office is part of a global corporation of Honeywell's size. It is that bureaucratic.
2. The supposedly scientific Honeywell Performance and Development (performance review) process is treated like a joke here. It is an open secret that people in Gurgaon are given pay hikes for no reason other than licking the boss' boots. 
3. So the boss wants to promote someone and can't find an opportunity to do it? Let's create a new position and elevate one of his cronies. Yes, it is that simple. 
4. If you are a woman, I am not sure this is the place for you. Recruiters are known to ask about pregnancy plans (I believe this is Gurgaon specific again). One of the managers in Gurgaon refused to entertain an existing female employee's  application to move to his team because she was in a live-in relationship with her husband (also an employee) before marriage.  
4. Men get away with a lot of behaviour that a woman may not. I have seen a male team leader yell at his team member in front of the entire team and perform poorly and yet, get away it. Try that as a woman and you have a behaviour problem.

review_title: Not employee friendly, no transparancy, brutal culture
job_title: Senior Human Resources Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Grabbing here...Paycheck came on time?
cons:
Zero employee focus unless there is a problem, then you get more focus than any one person can handle.

Employees are used to meet numbers for shareholders...not making numbers at quarter end, furloughs, pay cuts, layoffs. Not making year, benefit cuts, more layoffs, cancel hiring.

Zero tranparency. You can count on that most of what little you are told, will be half the truth or spun. 

Lots of complaints about HR, while I agree they are not the smartest bunch of office mates there at HoneyHell, I was one of them after all so first hand experience,  HR doesn't control anything, the upper management puppeteers everything, HR just gets the honkr to be the face to the employee. 

Employee surveys...wow...the idea to fix morale and engagement through employee clubs??  Pretty sure thats just not doing it. 

Constant layoffs and furloughs, constant. How does it feel to come to work each day not knowing if that day is "the" day? Brutal, I was there.

How can you pay bills when there are constant furloughs? Only managers bonus so think about this when you are laid off...your manager, execs, etc still get their bonuses even when there were layoffs in the department or function. How does that feel?!?! How is that even legal? Shouldn't be and I couldn't be a part of it any longer, hence I left.

review_title: Honeywell Cuts Costs Every Chance it Gets
job_title: Senior Manager, Customer Support in Minneapolis, MN
pros: World class co-workers working on some of the most innovative technology in the Aerospace industry.  Good base pay.  Industry-leading initiatives in production productivity and marketing activity.
cons:
The benefits are awful and keep getting worse.  Honeywell pioneered medical testing for its entire employee base annually.  We have only sky high deductible plans for medical and nothing special in any other areas.  

Honeywell Aerospace has had multiple years with no raises and multiple furloughs and layoffs since I joined a few years ago.  Many positions have relocated to low-cost regions.  I have never felt like my job is secure at this company.

The site facilities are awful, the cafeterias have awful food with no options and they close early for every meal.  There is no on-site IT support for computer or printer issues.  I can't even use the garbage can in my cube for food waste because they don't pick up garbage every night so all food waste has to go in the central garbage.  

They have no consideration for quality of life or work / life balance.  Telecommuting regularly is no longer allowed.  Health or child care facilities are not available on-site.  The only common space is the cafeteria, so socializing is difficult.  They have even eliminated annual barbeques, Christmas parties, etc.  This place is just soul sucking and no fun.

review_title: Smooth, Straighforward, but poor advancement in my department
job_title: Senior Mechanical Engineer in Torrance, CA
pros:
Company process is well-defined, methodical, predictable, and (at my low level, at least) not very political.
No infighting
Relatively fixed schedule in Aerospace, "9-5" job, no overtime
They understand the technology very well and know how to build, analyze, and test it. 
The fact that company process is generally well structured makes this a good choice for new college hires struggling to get their bearings. There's a resource for anything and everything they will need to know, and people like sharing their knowledge.
cons:
It's not an R&D company, everything is designed "by the book". Don't expect to come up with any new ideas that will actually be adopted inside of 20 years, no matter what you come up with in your Six Sigma project.

My boss was very rigid on hours and had me using PTO for appointments even though I was salaried. Not all departments are like this, though. Aerospace hours tracking is typical for the industry (down to 6-minute increments). I've since moved to a company that doesn't track hours at all, it's very refreshing.

Torrance is mostly older people. Everyone's very competent, but there's no social environment there. People clock out and go straight home.

No promotions unless you transfer to another department to get it. They are happy to let you do one job for 30+ years and never give more than a COL raise. That said, if you're looking for that sort of stability, it's there.

pros: Good company to start with and flexible working hours but depends on project to project
cons: After  completion of 1 year story starts , If you are among the unfortunate and special one chosen by your manager or by the management,you will be a part of  RIF and placed in the most awesome self improvement program  that is called as PIP. You will mostly be placed in PIP for a period from 30 days to 90 days  and  which will be used against you  and only for documentation. Your manager will be in super active agile process mode with meetings and feedback every week even though your manager  would have skipped some essential meetings in the past. Writing is on the wall you have to go. PIP is used as a tool for RIF. Be cautious after  completing one year. its about surviving year after year. Be careful with the Mid-Term, essentially you get a bad mid term even if you do your best your annual appraisal will be  really bad. The management is using PIP as a tool to show the door even though your team is doing overall good. Check your manager behavior if he is ought to get  its better to leave the company and look for a job elsewhere. Even your past good records will be ignored if placed under PIP. Its about surviving year to year now in this company.

pros: If you're lucky once you get on the road you will get experience that would take 10+ years elsewhere to get.  They put confidence in young engineers that no other company would, which if you're up for a challenge is perfect.

The pay is terrible for the industry, as it always has been,  but the benefits that made it worthwhile have completely disappeared in the last five years.  80 hour workweeks while abroad with no vacation nor holidays is the norm.  FOS managers are petty and will spite people they talk to three times a year like children.  The FOS managers also lie to other managers among the company to keep their shady practices under wraps.  The management is now all in the Honeywell mindset, which will simply not work for this type of company.  When field workers charging thousands a day to the customers are begging the customers for transportation, translators, and food, unlike any other licensor out there, it is embarrassing.

review_title: Good for oldies... Freshers can keep this in mind and return to this company after a decade!!
pros: Honeywell has a good brand name. The perks and benefits are excellent for senior employees. Salary is generally equal to or higher than industry standards. Honeywell is very established. Job security for those working in India is very high (Mostly because Indians work for cheaper). There is a lot of flexibility in timings. Sometimes employees are allowed to work from home. But this depends entirely on the nature of your immediate boss. There is plenty of recognition and awards for outstanding work. Overall, it is a great company to work in, for people with 7+ yrs of experience.
cons: Not at all a good place for freshers. Fresh engineering graduates are always given really small jobs, that nobody else would want to do. These jobs usually dont require engineering skills. And there is no scope for improvement or growth for employees joining in as freshers. The oldies are usually stuck in really good high posts, so there is not much scope for the youngsters. Too much money is spent on the senior employees who do not deliver much and not many oppurtunitites for a fresher in the company. The kind of work you do, does not align with your interests. It is just pure luck! There is a lack of life in office, due to lack of energetic and young people. What else can you expect when there are so many oldies in the campany... Work environment SUCKS!!

They push very hard for overtime, yet they have no idea where that time is spent. The result is that the same people abuse the overtime when there is no work to justify it. Huge emphasis on safety & improvement ideas, but this is only to pad the metrics for a manager or director. Immediate supervisor really clueless and rarely gives positive feedback. Very demoralizing environment. With the current management it will never realize it's full potential.
The current HOS system is a one size fits all and no one there has the guts to tell Mr Cote that guess what, one size does not fit all. I guess that when you have dysfunctional management you cannot trust them to run the show so you have to come up with an act that will satisfy the shareholders. Touche Mr Cote. You are a great ringleader with the circus you call HOS.

review_title: Honeywell is a great technology company. They have incredible resources and people but are wall street focused
pros:
* Great technology - Much of the technology is all self developed - Best process technology world wide
* Great Talent
* Solid benefits  
* Stable business
* Recognized Name
cons:
* Lost touch with customer results - Focused on Wall Street Metrics over customer business results (You know, the people who buy what you make...???)
* Follow GE business practices like a shadow - Not original any more
* Too conservative so risk adverse it impedes growth
* Weak Sales and Marketing front - Consumed so much with cost of sales they cannot reach customers
* No bandwidth in Marketing
* No vision - Only invest in mature technologies
* Myopic - Only see things in the Honeywell world. 
* Not embracing entrepreneurial attitudes -they would like to be, tout the talk, but are process regimented and mute individual thinking. All goals and objectives have to follow word for word what management instructs. No latitude for individual responsibility.   "Bill Gates would have been fired here in a week!"
* Too many Ladder Climbers - Passion to drive business is lost. Leadership places unqualified leadership into unknown business sectors because they are politically connected. (Its the Allied way) Assumption? If they did good in one role they are good in another role. To drive any business you must have passion for that business.

review_title: Incompetency, Politics, & Selfishness at the managerial level
job_title: Process Design Engineer in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: International exposure giving you a chance to interact with, and learn from, industry specialists. A good brand  value in refining/petrochemical business.
cons:
Culture: Incompetency, Politics, & Selfishness at the managerial level in gurgaon office. 
Recruitment, training, and growth opportunities are reserved by managers to only the candidates coming from either eastern india (bengal), or southern india (chennai). You should be ready to accept that almost all the managerial positions, or lead positions, are occupied by either a bengali or a chennai guy...performance evaluation and yearly appraisals are 100% biased....managers are technically absolutely incompetent, and only knows dirty politics to insure getting THEIR (bengali/south indian) guys in key positions....they themselves got to managerial positions without working at all!!....if you are a bengali or a south indian candidate, then this is your place (mecca)....others, pl do not waste your time....one entire technology center has ALL the candidates coming from south india!!....even the anonymous feedbacks aren't anonymous, and the next day your manager would talk to you about the feedback...managers nominate THEIR guys for good assignments, or career progression....everything is evident, but no one could do anything about this.... managers are enjoying easy money with collaborative political efforts, and screwing lives of working level engineers....it sums up to the fact that the managers in gurgaon office are absolutely not adding any value to this company...very unfortunate for a prestigious organization.

pros:
Overall very good company in terms of work opportunities as well as onsite opportunities.  
Work culture is very decent and mostly same across all BU's.
Most people think Honeywell Pune is only for Instru and E&TC guys, I am Comp Engg. and till now got very good challenging opportunities in CPP, C#, ASP.NET & SQL Server.  
I belong to Advanced Solutions which is very sophisticated and IT like behaving unit (not worked for other units so no idea regarding other units). The people are great and treat each other great. Lots of activities going on for everyone like Language Training, Lead Training, Customer Handling Training and Fun activities like Festival Celebrations, Competitions, Get together and Team Outings.
Very good structure for Awards and Recognition. HR persons are very approachable and ready to work on issues.
I have seen if person is ready to take responsibilities and confident enough then Management is always ready to take risks and bear learning curve.
Gym facility is very good and economical.
cons:
Salary is less compare to IT Industry standards for Comp guys. 
Growth is little slower compare to IT Industry. 
I have seen many Old managers still want to micro manage employees by tracking Entry and Exit time, also for some old managers I have seen going home at 6:30 or 7 is issue, they enjoy working till 9 without proper workload and expects same behavior from team.
Canteen is still following 15% GST structure, no use of escalations as every time they give lame reason for not following new 5% GST structure.

Some good, clever engineers to be found there. Good people in general.

cons:
Opinions: Too much work is outsourced.  
Concept of  getting 24 hours of operation with off-shore outsourcing does not work effectively. 
Domestic cohesiveness, the oneness and pride in ones work have suffered from outsourcing. 

Many schedules are simply unrealistic and doomed to run late and over-budget. 

Fear of  a layoff has become an implicit driver to overwork the engineers. 

Observations: Domestic engineers have become mostly facilitators and auditors. 
Direct engineers are over-worked. There are frequent layoffs, particularly with contractors.
Cost-cutting methods are sometimes baffling. Someone once said Honeywell will spend $100 just to save $5!

pros: Was once a great innovator in Aerospace before Allied Signal acquired Honeywell and turned it into Honey-Ah-Lied.  Still has some great engineers for new grads to work with, but very little new development to learn from, as management wants to "milk" the old products rather than invest in new development..  Benefits and pay were comparable to other aerospace companies, but the benefits have been steadily eroded for several years, including actual 10% pay cuts in 2009.
cons: Upper management's entire  focus is to outsource everything to save money -- even if the engineering work and manufactured products coming out of the outsourcing are shoddy.  Upper management takes no responsibility for the product problems and only wants more work outsourced while experienced engineers are laid off or pushed to retire due to benefit cuts.  The company is being driven into the ground by greedy corporate executives who don't contribute any real leadership or vision for the future of the company. The profits generated by all the cost savings go to bloated executive salaries and buying other businesses to pillage.  The first thing the management does after an acquisition is to sell off all the buildings and land of the new business (and lease back the buildings) to pretend that they have made a profit.  Then the outsourcing and layoffs begin, followed by the stifling of any investment in new products.  Basically it's a cannibalistic company, devouring any resources and terminating employees.

review_title: The Honeywell Phoenix Engines site has a culture that is apathetic and oppressive at best.
job_title: Health, Safety and Environmental Engineer II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Honeywell offers reasonable salaries and plenty of room for movement.  Many of the Honeywell locations have numerous opportunities for training, as well.
cons:
Although Honeywell offers competitive salaries, the benefits package is completely inadequate.  They don't start contributing to your 401(k) until you have been contributing for at least 3 years, and then they only match at up to 3% of your salary at ~35 cents per dollar matching.  They also have a very expensive medical insurance plan.  The company is self insured, and they charge employees several hundred dollars each month for medical insurance that has a deductible of $8000 for a family; this effectively requires a family to spend ~$12,000 before the medical insurance pays anything at all.  

The Honeywell Phoenix Engines site is an oppressive work environment.  The employees that have been working there for many years are defeated and feel like no one cares about them or their opinions because management in unresponsive or very slow to respond.  New employees are frustrated because they get no orientation or training, and then are "held accountable" for information they never had an opportunity to learn.  The management system is very punitive, not supportive in any way.  Employees are punished harshly, and tearing other people down in order advance yourself is encouraged.

pros:
Work is not very difficult and you are given plenty of time to complete it. Even if you fail to meet milestones, the feature will be descoped or postponed anyway. So it is very easy to achieve work/life balance. Hours are flexible and it is possible to work from home. 

Work is not checked over by managers so you can exaggerate your accomplishments during meetings and take credit for the work of others to build a reputation. Even an individual contributor can average 8 hours of meetings a week, so there are plenty of excuses for falling behind. 

You don't necessarily need to understand how the product works in order to be a manager, you can just deflect questions to someone else.  Managers don't need to be involved in development if there are lack of resources, their only responsibility is to give opinions at meetings.  Talented people leave the company, so there is plenty of space to move up.

Job is quite secure.
cons:
People who have worked there 10+ years don't necessarily understand the product much more than a new employee.  There seems to be a lack of good problem solvers, so those who are competent are burdened with all the debugging and bug fixing.

Excessive processes and micromanaging.  No autonomy, no ownership of work.  Pace of development is quite slow.

Code base is outdated and built on deprecated technologies, very difficult to innovate.

Lots of restrictions on what software you can install, excessive blocking of internet access.

Technical excellence doesn't seem to be valued much.

pros: Name recognition . Can’t think of any others.
cons:
So many...notice a trend in these reviews? Awful benefits, HR policies that are decidedly anti-employee, lack of training, high stress, high overtime, understaffed.

I have found all of these to be true. I work in the Aerospace business in Tempe, AZ and compared to other area contractors, it is painfully obvious that Honeywell doesn’t care enough about employees to try to be competitive. There’s more of a “let’s see how much we can get out of them before they quit mentality” here. The irony is the surprise when certain areas of the company experience high turnover. It’s a pretty clear indicator of a bad company when you can’t get anyone to accept or interview for positions on your team because your reputation is so bad.

Also work from home is a pretty standard modern benefit. Good companies allow it because they trust their employees and know that it encourages employee retention and productivity. You guessed it. Honeywell no longer allows work from home without a prohibitive and antiquated review and approval process. It’s ridiculous and the reasons given for eliminating this benefit were crap! Team building, productivity, blah, blah. Maybe when we’re required to work overtime on our personal time we should cite the work from home policy and refuse since technically we can’t work from home? It’s such a hypocritical change.

You'll come out knowing more than all of the other students at your respective college, and you can impress future employers with your ability to fully describe the chemistry and mechanics behind oil refinery.

-Get competitive with pay! (like everyone has already said!) You lost THIS intern because that low ball 48k offer.

review_title: One of my most favorite companies I have worked for

cons: This feedback is more with reference to Honeywell TS India. There is a lot of politics and your manager can make or break your career without HR having any say whatsoever. Extremely poor work-life balance and you would be asked to work like a dog with little or no appreciation. To make matters worse, if get an unfair lady boss, your fate is is sealed. You will have to search for a new job as no one can help you because of the 'diversity' initiative. The reason why I don't work at Honeywell anymore. The pay would be probably at the 85th percentile.

job_title: Design Engineer II in Calgary, AB
pros: Pay and benefits are reasonable to good. In general, most of the work you get to do here will have some global impact and in keeping with that you'll get exposure to a diverse, global workforce. Hiring policies are conservative - this means tight headcount control, but positions are generally safe compared to other organizations which go overboard hiring people who mere months later will be on the street again. Read a 2010-ish HBR article in which the Honeywell CEO articulates his rationale for furloughing employees during the 2008 downturn very well - as opposed to engaging in the perpetual layoff-rehire cycle so characteristic elsewhere. Kudos!
cons: Much of the organization is acquisition based rather than homegrown. Core pieces of knowledge and process assets are seldom centralized and remain at the periphery, i.e. the acquired lines of business. At the same time the company has poor vertical and horizontal alignment. Vertically, a towering stack of middle management levels (last I counted 9 between me and the CEO) leads to diffuse responsibility but maintains a surprisingly authoritarian command and control approach. Horizontally this is matched by extreme silo formation. Management longevity is poor. At some point in my career I had to deal with a veritable revolving door of supervisors (and their supervisors, and so forth).

review_title: Fun and Interesting Place to Work, Sad State at the Company
pros: Programs are fun to work on. There is a wealth of knowledge from employees who have been  there many years. Mots of mentor ship opportunities if you seek out and build relationships with the right experts. Most of the employees are fun to work with. There is tons to learn if you pay attention and strive to build knowledge.
cons: Benefits are horrible. Cost cutting in all the wrong places. Departments merging that have nothing to do with one another. Employees are some what beat down with RIFS and Furloughs hanging over your head all the time. Quality and customer service would suffer if the employees didn't actually care and didn't work twice as hard like they do. Its very hard to move up unless you job hop, which creates a bunch of people who are mediocre at their jobs and gaps when they move to another department.

job_title: Senior Engineer/Scientist, Research Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Not a lot!  Used to be a company that valued employees knowledge and experience and rewarded hard work.  Salaries were not always the highest, but good benefits and good company morale made up the difference.
cons: I retired before I wanted to because I could see the company being destroyed by short-sighted management who only looked at how much cash could be stripped from the company over the next quarter.  Benefits had become a joke and managers had no real power.  VERY top down management style!  Projects were started and then ended if no quick return on investment was seen as being in the next quarter!  Following company slogans and management fads became more important than actually achieving results!

job_title: Senior Human Resources Business Partner in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
Honeywell is a company with a story of making huge breakthrough innovations that have had a wide impact in the world. All employees are very passionate of what we make, be it engines, molecules, detectors and now quantum computers.
It's a strong performance culture, and it has shown that it will grow organizational muscles by doing hard work. An example of that are the 2 spins of Garrett and Resideo. Strong assets for Honeywell accounting for almost 20% of revenue.  All of us worked in some capacity some extra time and effort to help that those spins were successful and they are. I'm not sure how many companies are out there that can tell a story like that.
Finally, Honeywell is really living up to live it's guiding behaviors especially in terms of diversity and inclusion. Being a minority in the US has never been an issue in the company and I have always felt I have a voice and that my unique way of thinking is always taken seriously.
cons:
Health benefits are on par with market, but are not great... 
As a very consensus driven company, decisions are slow. At then end you mitigate risks as you considered all points of view, but sometimes you move in a pace that competition beats you.

pros:
+ brand name
+ good compensation
+ flexible work timings
+ free covered parking
+ cafe has multiple vendors and food appears to be prepared hygienically
+ free six sigma trainings and certification opportunities
+ lean and process improvement thinking (HOS Gold)
+ great focus on UX and a big team for organization-wide UX activities
+ HR works closely with the IT function
cons:
- pushy recruiters and hiring managers are hand-in-glove in pressurizing candidates for an early joining, often dropping fake news of alternative candidates who will be considered for the same role
- work in the IT function is largely application support; not many new projects
- job roles and responsibilities lack clear definition and boundaries. I had to play the roles of a functional analyst, project manager and support team lead (some long-termers find that very special)
- career path and growth opportunities are hazy
- little or no knowledge retention within the company, since development and support work are done by contract employees
- no co-located teams, since the contract employees work from another city (loners can rejoice)
- colleagues in the USA rarely adjust to IST, so work-life balance goes for a toss
- some colleagues (mostly long in the tooth ones) work long and late to earn brownie points
- no work from home option
- top management is very dense
- HOS Gold is all preach and zero practice
- no travel opportunities
- business analysis is an often ignored and under-developed discipline in the entire organization; BAs steer clear!
- software licences are shared, so you need to keep requesting IT Help Desk to renew/extend it for continued usage

review_title: Honeywell is not what the general public perceives it to be
pros: Pay is comparable to other engineering based companies, benefits are about average, facilities (at least in Golden Valley, MN) are nice after the remodeling, most of the rank-and-file are very hard working. Paychecks always cleared - although they were trying to extend T&Cs for vendors to 90 days or longer if possible.
cons:
I was a competitive hire, and after 20 months I returned to my previous employer. Honeywell is no longer the practical engineering company with a midwestern mindset that many people think it is. Specifics:
- SAP at any cost ($60M per year, 5 years running and at least 3 years remaining). Original window was 4-5 years. Unfortunately, several strategic mistakes were made in planning, and this has cost the company millions.
- Six Sigma for most everyone, even if you must fly to another city to be trained. Half the people in my class did not understand the basics of statistics, problem solving, etc. 
- More meetings with people who did not contribute a single comment, take responsibility for an action, or otherwise participate. Since many meetings are hosted "remotely" (using LiveMeeting or similar tools), often people who should have been listening and participating were busy reading their email or checking their BBs. 
- Stated targets for back-office functions (IT, procurement, etc) were based on industry "best-in-class" comparisons, but after probing for additional details the basis for these comparisons were never provided.

pros: Great technologies, good life-work balance, and excellent learning opportunities. A very good brand in the refining industry. It has been a reference in refining and petrochemicals. However, seems that Honeywell is changing even the brand of UOP into Honeywell...
cons: Since the day Honeywell started integrating UOP into its PMT business, things started to change. The company structure used to be lean. Now, it is vertical with many layers of managers. In fact, I think that the managers are more than the regular employees in the company. The processes became very centralized which led to many organizational dysfunctions. The top management has been changing regularly, with very limited opportunities for other employees to advance in the organization. I believe that if you do not have a big sponsor or you do not play back-channel politics nowadays, there is no way for you to advance in the organization. I agree with the one who said that Honeywell is converting UOP into a software company. A lot of talents left the company, especially those who are competent enough to get jobs in the market.

job_title: Engineer I Mechanical in Aguadilla, PR
pros:
Good standard benefit package (401k, Health/Med Plan, Life Insurance, Company matching), great people making part of great teams no matter what position you are in. Employee discounts, great innovative/helpful site management, higher paying than many other engineering opportunities in PR.

Flexible work hours, good cafeterias in both PR sites.
cons:
Good engineers keep waiting to get noticed, promotions in Puerto Rico have become slow, almost halted across many teams even when they are going above and beyond their current roles for less than national average pay in a U.S. territory that just gets more expensive/exclusive. The educational assistance was a catch, in my case. Management made it look as if everyone gets a chance and that you can get started quick after a year with the company, but they have made it impossible for me to obtain approvals to continue studying in related fields (after more than 2 years) and in cases where I have had the opportunity to grow and learn from other design tools I have been slamed with a no for an answer in front of other peers. (Almost makes it feel like they really didn't want me to grow).

Many employee discounts for PR are irrelevant or outdated to local stores and discounts available are less than half of those in U.S mainland... worst than that... company products offered to employees at a diacounted price are actually cheaper in Amazon for everyone to buy.

pros: People are a differentiation and in general there are fantastic people working for Honeywell and it is is a pleasure to work side by side with them. Being a large corporate, there are also good opportunities to learn and develop as an individual.
cons:
From a benefits perspective, Honeywell is really not an attractive proposition to attract people and it stacks up poorly against its counterparts. Most recently, healthcare has been removed entirely as a paid benefit and pension contribution is down to a flat 1% for any new employee. All other "benefits" are salary sacrifice for employees where you can get better deals by shopping around 
There is a constant cycle and environment of change with little stability and Honeywell has forgotten how to manage people successfully through any change with the consequence being very low levels of moral and high levels of resentment among the employees. This has led to people voting with their feet and the business hemorrhaging key staff members, with Honeywell for whatever strategic reason not attempting to stem the bleed....
If you are looking for a dynamic, energized, entrepreneurial environment in which to work Honeywell is not for you!

review_title: Not bad but could be better
pros: Diverse products allowing pursuit of different careers. Many national and international sites giving opportunities to move.  Strong focus on high tech products - jet engines and flight guidance/management systems - military and commercial products. There are reasonable training opportunities and a reasonable support for initiatives such as Six Sigma and Lean. If you take the initiative and know what you are doing, build consensus and get the right level of support it is possible to move the needle on things you initiate/believe in  - and not just follow Leadership initiatives. There us a huge gap in the demographics - lots of 20+ year folk, many younger people but few "middle managers" in the 10 -15 year range - so opportunnities will be growing as teh old guard retires.
cons: It's a big corporation and the better you are at your job the more work you get. Slackers get to cruise. Cost of benefits far outstripping salaries. No respect for company service - they will cram someone with 10, 15, 20 years service in the same cubicle as someone who just joined the company - usually both of them in the same cubicle. Corporate policies are followed only when convenient - rules say you fly business class if a flight is over 8 hours, bosses say "fly in the back". Of course this only applies if you don' fly on one of the many corporate jets that the "leaders" fly around in.

No Raises or Promotions - Frequent cutbacks to benefits while Honeywell brags about how much profit they make. No raises for 2 years with taxes increasing means take-home pay has gone down
Disorganization - no training, no mentorship, trial by fire

job_title: Vertical Business Leader in Perth, Western Australia
pros:
- Lots of career development opportunities if you are up for a challenge
(I started with Honeywell as a Graduate Engineer 33 years ago. I spent my first 14 years in Project Operations moving from project engineering to project management then project operations leadership. The past 19 years of my career have been in Sales & Business Development moving from project sales to CIP security sales leadership and then to my curent role as Vertical Business Leader for Justice & Corrections for HBS Pacific)

review_title: A decent tech company whose benefits are struggling due to a "slow-growth economy"
job_title: Systems Engineer I in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
-Exciting projects with some competitive technology
-My coworkers and boss are very helpful and will make time for each other, with little micro-management
-Fewer pointless meeting for low-level employees than other companies
-As a large company, it brings a lot of expertise and products that have been heavily refined over the years
-Many people work here for at least a decade
-401k and flexible working hours
cons:
-The company, especially Aerospace, is financially struggling and has announced several furloughs and layoffs every quarter of 2016
-Doesn't allow employees to work from home regularly because they place "bumping into each other in the cafeteria" over flexible work/life balance, despite having teams spread over several countries
-A significant amount of work is outsourced making collaboration difficult.
-No company contributions to dental and high-deductible medical coverage because "money is best managed by the employee"
-Current raises, including merit raises are rare
-The company is too "cost-focused" to invest in fixing glaring efficiency issues or filling empty positions on overworked teams
-Less investment in a 'great place to work" than other companies I've worked for (i.e. virtually no employer-sponsored networking, special events, new employee opportunities, special career growth programs)
-Failure to meet financial goals are rarely blamed on leadership and instead blamed on the "slow-growth" economy.

review_title: A dream environment...if you have no soul
pros: Few and far between.  You might be lucky enough to work for a business that overdelivers on its numbers for a period or for the rare executive who is a decent human being.  But that will change soon enough.
cons:
Are you a person who would slit your dear mother's throat to "make the numbers" and for a promotion opportunity?  Congratulations, you would be on the fast track to upper management at Honeywell!  No matter what the company says about the importance of exhibiting the right behaviors, the only thing that matters is the numbers.  If you are ambitious yet are saddled by a conscience, you need not apply.  You'll stand no chance.

Oh, and the medical benefits are among the worst employer could possibly offer.  It was like getting an early Christmas present each year when HR announced the requisite 4-5% cost increase, with the corresponding pay freeze (of course).  The cost of Obamacare was rapidly converging with this massive corporation's medical benefits and it's only a matter of time before it becomes cheaper.

You will also receive the privilege of learning how to perfect beuracracy and spend endless hours making meaningless powerpoint slides, better known internally as the "journey to HOS Gold".

Seriously, if you are considering a position here, you've been warned.  Take a job only if you are desperate, and get out as quickly as you can.  The only people that I knew at the company that are truly content are those that checked out mentally long ago.

pros: "unlimited" vacation...… this is nice when it's actually approved.  the people are the best thing about this company.  However, all of the good people are leaving.
cons:
Been here for almost two years now.  I came in on the merger process when Honeywell was taking over.  I always though of Honeywell as a great company to work for until I worked for them.   Benefits changed drastically and the 401k is not as good as it used to be; they actually hold it until the end of the year to give you the match which allows them to collect interest on it.  Hiring freezes which keep employees from seeking other opportunities within the company.  Recently learned that Honeywell furloughs people at least once a year for a few weeks even if your branch of the company is profitable.  
There is no work/life balance at this company.  They preach separating your work from your home life but how is that expected when you are working long weekends and away from your family for weeks on end.  
It would have been nice to take this job knowing that there is a potential to be furloughed .

job_title: Field Service Adviser in Chicago, IL
pros: Great training program. Excellent on-site opportunities. Massive projects. Opportunity to work in cross-functional teams. Salaries higher than what market offers. If your manager coaches you well, you can climb the corporate ladder really fast.
cons: Not much interest in employee retention. Performance reviews are solely based on external feedback. Manager has very little role to play in employee's performance and motivation. They are least concerned. They do not try to find time to speak with employees if they receive negative feedback. They do not bother to check if they feedback presents only one face of the coin. Other than the performance reviews, most processes are fairly organized.

pros: Lots of opportunities, especially if mobile. As a conglomerate, Honeywell is in a lot of exciting industries where you can make an impact.. Pay is competitive and performance is rewarded. Challenging, meaningful work. A lot of managers who truly care about their employee's. New CEO has been moving things in a really positive direction that is much more employee centric. Recent branding campaign shows he values how Honeywell is seen to everyone, not just shareholders.
cons: Inconsistent practices across sites and a lot of extra layers. Change management is often an after thought and the mechanisms used don't translate well for different employee types (i.e way you roll something out at an office setting is very different than how it should be done at a manufacturing site). As global as the company is, could do more for our employee's outside the US to make it more regionally relevant to them. Health insurance is also very expensive & could be improved through alternate benefit options (i.e reimburse portions of gym memberships, student loan paydowns,etc)

review_title: Stability at the price of stagnation
job_title: Chemical Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros: You have the pleasure of working with some of the smartest people in the industry. The company itself is known and respected (mostly for good reason) throughout the industry. A great place to learn refining & petrochemicals. Don't take the brevity of these pro comments as condemnation - just know that in general the people here (particularly Technical Service) are a pleasure to work with, and played rightly, one learns something new every day. If financial compensation is not your motivator, then there is no better place to work.
cons: It is difficult to see the benefit of 'staying the course' and working in a job for the period of time required to truly become an expert. I have no doubt that the industry-recognized experts are well compensated for the value they provide to the company, but it seems like everyone is either a new/recent hire or a 30+ year employee, expert on everything under the sun. The middle ground is scant and difficult to see.

review_title: Decent work/home life balance, mediocre pay
pros:
Work/home life balance
Very flexible hours - as long as you work 40 per week, nobody really complains
Overtime available and sometimes required
Easy to excel at your position, as the others that get rated with you tend to be older and less inclined to learn new technology.
cons:
Health/dental packages suck. Enough said.
Too many bosses - Service Operations Manager, Field Service Manager, Field Operations Leader, On-Site Leader
Good Old Boys Club - If you're not in the inner circle or work at a site with a big contract, then you sort of get lost in the shadows of the bigger contracts and the sites that get more hands on from the upper management. 
Record Profits for the Company = One pay raise in four years and no bonuses...ever
Lack of formal, classroom training - You will learn most things on site from other technicians

review_title: Not what it used to be...
pros: The work is exciting. My team, and leadership is great and really care about people. They understand work/life balance and motivate team to go above and beyond to meet goals.
cons: However, executive leadership does not care for the employees. Market is down and hard decisions need to be made, however, leadership does not think of the team when making these decisions. They give as little as 2-3 week notice for furloughs and layoffs. When asked about future activities, their response is always the same..."nothing is planned". However, a month or so later an announcement comes out about another furlough/lay off. It is foolish for executives to believe employees do not know our leaders are looking into the future. They know in advance if actions are needed and yet, they refuse to help their employees by giving as much notice as possible. They don't care. Then to add, a few weeks ago, it was announced no longer remote working was allowed...We just step backed into the 80's. No other fortune 500 company believes in this philosophy. If Honeywell is looking for people to quit to avoid another layoff, they will get it, the problem is their high performing employees will quit and they will be left with what is left.

review_title: HUGE company trying to stay relevant
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ciudad de Mexico
pros: This huge company has very solid branding and very interesting products. People is nice, quiet and overall friendly, at least where I am. Harassement and bullying are not tolerated so it's a place you can focus on doing your job right. There's a lot of opportunites inside. Lots of people trying to improve things. Good culture.
cons: Honeywell is so big that it can be a huge city by itself. There are so many different business units that you will be easily overwhelmed. You can be seated next to a person that is not related at all with the products you work on. There are lots of changes in the company, budget stuff and people that have left, but there's also lots of people trying to improve things. I picture Honeywell as a giant trojan horse with lots of people inside it, trying to move everything as fast as they can, but the world already has rockets and space ships. It's very bureaucratic. No parking space for newbies in Mexico City, it's full.

review_title: Don't Waste Your Time With Honeywell
pros:
- The Honeywell name (which looks good on a resume now, but will likely be a con soon)
- A few decent benefits, but declining rapidly
cons:
- Too many to list, but I'll try
- Management is non-existent
- Engineering teams cross multiple continents with very poor communication and the usual time-zone issues, which the incompetent employees exploit repeatedly
- Work from home policy was recently canceled, with a serious hit to productivity and general resentment
- They layoff people in small batches, spread over the year, so you never feel safe from one layoff to the next
- Indian software engineers are (for the most part) very incompetent
- Chinese engineers are slightly more technically competent than the Indian engineers, but they could care less about employees in North America. You have to basically copy someone's manager and their manager's manager on an email to get an answer from them most of the time.
- Quality is abysmal and products are over-priced
- Customer issues take forever to solve because resources are allocated for only the most serious problems (i.e. impending lawsuits and multi-million dollar penalties)
- The whole company seems to be run by salesmen who over-sell (i.e. lie) to customers and bean-counters who only see unit-level costs and not overall cost (i.e. sure, widget X is $1 cheaper than widget Y, but widget Y is 10-times harder to operate, so you'll have (A) way more ticked off customers and (B) have to hire additional tech support personnel).
- No real vision for the company
- Way, wayyyyyyy too many products for each product space. 
- CEO pledged to become the "Apple of the Industry" in 2013...failed miserably

Microsoft shop (heavy Azure). Clueless leadership who don't understand software development. Values social issues and progressivism over working products. HR and hiring are a nightmare. People are promoted and rewarded for behavior that would be considered fireable elsewhere. Company promotes competition between its own business units in a way that creates a toxic atmosphere instead of healthy competition. Security and Ops stuck in an old school mindset that is counterproductive to actual network security, stifles innovation, and are combative towards development teams. No input or control for developers over tools and software they have to use and support on a daily basis. Bureaucracy everywhere. SAFe agile. Poor work-life balance. Other offices in the company are run-down, sad, and possibly unsafe with mold and asbestos.

review_title: Lackluster raises, losing experienced engineers, little to no  guidance/training
pros: I'm honestly not sure. It is fairly easy to move between groups/roles. But this is limited to once every 18 months. This is the only way to get a raises that beats inflation.
cons:
Raises:

In my time at Honeywell I have never actually received a raise that was higher than that years inflation. The only way you'll be able to get an actual pay increase at this company is to switch to a different role. 

Losing experience:

Honeywell is losing engineers quickly. Mainly due to retirement, and there are no engineers to take their place. There has been no foresight to hire and train people to fill the shoes of these engineering giants as they leave. 

No guidance/training:

When getting a job here, there is little to no guidance or training on how to preform your new role. I don't think I've actually ever been trained on how to do something at this company. I've had to figure it out myself, or if I'm lucky, I can get someone to reply to one of my emails or answer a call for a few seconds to tell me what needs to be done. 

Work/life balance:

There is a constant push from the higher ups to work more. This is tracked and we are constantly urged to put in more hours in order to help Honeywell reduce labor cost and push out contracts quicker.
